item.title: Timothée Chalamet Draws Huge Crowd for ‘Marty Supreme’ Merch Pop-Up
item.description: Mr. Chalamet’s star power was in full force in Manhattan as fans clamored to get merch for “Marty Supreme,” a movie none of them will see until Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher and Graham Dickie
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times

item.title: Gown at Governors Awards Red Carpet Put Its Designer on the Map. What’s Next?
item.description: A gown that made waves at a recent awards ceremony was created in a pinch — and put its designer on the map.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi

item.title: At Loyola Marymount’s KXLU, College Radio Keeps Its Cool
item.description: Against the odds, campus broadcasts remain a space of discovery, for students and listeners alike. Especially at KXLU in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Deuel and Adali Schell
item.media:description: Carmela Michaeli is the music director at KXLU, a popular college radio station at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles.

item.title: How the Quarter-Zip Sweater Became a Symbol of Maturity for Gen Z
item.description: How one of the stodgiest garments in the Western wardrobe caught on with the Nike Tech crowd.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia

item.title: Guinness Record for World’s Largest Afro Broken by Jessica Martinez
item.description: With an Afro that is more than six feet in circumference, Jessica Martinez set a new Guinness record.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Bill Ackman Shared Dating Advice for Young Men. Not Everyone Swooned.
item.description: The billionaire investor proposed a four-word solution for young men’s romantic woes.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Is Scalp Care the New Big Beauty Trend?
item.description: Consumers are increasingly fixating on their scalps, turning to head spas, pricey treatments and products to combat thin hair and irritation.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus
item.media:credit: Winnie Au for The New York Times
item.media:description: The focus on scalps “took time until people were finally interested in it, maybe five or six years ago, when American people started the self-care trend,” said Ritsuko Borges, the founder of the Japanese head spa Masa.Kanai in Manhattan.

item.title: Meryl Streep and More Stars Toast Tom Hanks in ‘This World of Tomorrow’
item.description: A crowd that included Meryl Streep, Martin Short and Steve Martin packed the Shed for the actor’s new show, “This World of Tomorrow.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Ye Fan
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times

item.title: Share Your Most Memorable SantaCon Story
item.description: We’re gathering readers’ stories about one of New York’s most polarizing holiday traditions. Share your best, worst and wildest SantaCon memories here.
item.media:credit: Craig T Fruchtman/Getty Images

item.title: Solange Knowles, Librarian: Expanding a Saint Heron Passion Project
item.description: The Grammy winner, now a scholar in residence at U.S.C., is expanding a one-of-a-kind library featuring rare books by writers of color. (Just mind the due date.)
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus

item.title: The Rise of Luxury Micro Weddings
item.description: Some couples are opting for intimate celebrations, but they’re not scaling back their budgets. Instead, they’re investing in elevated menus, luxury flowers and unique venues.
item.dc:creator: Mina Llona

item.title: How Olivia Nuzzi and Ryan Lizza Became Main Characters on Social Media
item.description: Love, politics and ethics collided as Olivia Nuzzi and Ryan Lizza went at it in a media sphere that rewards private revelations.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Haddad Media
item.media:description: Olivia Nuzzi and Ryan Lizza in 2022, well before they lost their jobs as political writers for prestigious publications.

item.title: Vanity Fair Is Reviewing Its Ties to Olivia Nuzzi
item.description: The magazine, which recently hired the journalist, said it had been “taken by surprise” by new claims in an essay by her former fiancé, Ryan Lizza.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Olivia Nuzzi at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner in 2023.

item.title: Gift-Giving Tips: Expert Advice on Choosing the Perfect Present
item.description: Giving thoughtful gifts is a skill that some find easier than others. We asked a luxury gift concierge for her advice.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Four Months Into Dating, She Moved Across the Country with Him
item.description: When Seun Akinboboye asked his new girlfriend, Taylar Wade, to relocate to San Francisco, she didn’t want to wonder “what if.”
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: An Army Captain Asked His Server About Herself. She Wasn’t Interested (Yet).
item.description: Neither Shaylah Nichols nor Jordan Lee was looking for anything serious in Honolulu. A late-night talk and lots of laughs changed that.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: A Painful Family Discovery, and the Love Story That Followed
item.description: After a revelation about her ancestors, Elizabeth Thomas moved to Washington, D.C., found a fulfilling career and met Anthony Gregg.
item.dc:creator: Ama Sarpomaa

item.title: I Was Deemed Unfit to Be a Mother
item.description: After losing custody of my son, I fought to prove my love to him. That was a mistake.
item.dc:creator: Kate Gilgan
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: She Adopted on Her Own. Then Love Found Both of Them.
item.description: Amy Krasner assumed her love life was over when she became a single mother with a busy career. Then along came Douglas Robb.
item.dc:creator: Leslie Katz

item.title: Ward Landrigan, Jeweler to the Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: At Sotheby’s, he provided famous diamonds to Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton before reviving Verdura, a venerable jewelry company founded by a Sicilian duke.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Thomas Iannaccone/WWD, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Through his jewelry house Verdura, Ward Landrigan catered to high-society figures as well as celebrities like Brooke Shields, Sofia Coppola and the fashion designer Carolina Herrera.

item.title: Richard Lamparski, 93, Dies; Wrote ‘Whatever Became Of …?’ Books
item.description: He turned an obsession with forgotten stars into a popular series, long before “Where Are They Now?” features became ubiquitous.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Should I Confront My Friend About Her Affair?
item.description: We all reside in senior living, and she is carrying on with a man under his disabled wife’s nose.
item.dc:creator: Lori Gottlieb
item.media:credit: Marta Monteiro

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Dating Straight Boys’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Do You Use A.I. for College Application Advice?
item.description: We want to hear about it.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times

item.title: Bonnie Munshin, ‘Velvet Hammer’ of a Hamptons Hot Spot, Dies at 84
item.description: At Nick & Toni’s, a restaurant beloved by celebrities and locals alike, she managed its coveted prime real estate, keeping everyone happy and the looky-loos at bay.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Deidre Schoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bonnie Munshin at Nick & Toni’s in 2013. Seeing her at the restaurant, the actor Alec Baldwin said, was “like finding a lighthouse on a stormy sea.”

item.title: Alice and Ellen Kessler, ’60s Singing Sensations, Die at 89
item.description: The twin sisters from Germany, who were nightclub stars and regular guests on international variety shows, chose to end their lives together.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Karl Mittenzwei/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Kesslers at a news conference in 1997, presenting excerpts from a show based on their autobiography, “Eins Und Eins Ist Eins” (“One Plus One Is One”).

item.title: Kissing Has Existed for at Least 16 Million Years, Scientists Say
item.description: And humans are far from the only species locking lips.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Roland Weihrauch/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Orangutans were one of the species whom the scientists focused on in their study.

item.title: I Am Ambivalent About My Boyfriend. Who Can I Talk to About It?
item.description: A reader wonders what to make of the reservations she’s having about a yearlong relationship, and whom to share them with.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: Melania Trump’s Green Gown Signals Saudi Arabia Diplomatic Ties
item.description: At the official dinner for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the first lady offered an unexpected sign of allegiance.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Melania Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to the White House on Tuesday for a state dinner.

item.title: What Are Fashion Expatriates Into? Home Design.
item.description: Somerset House, a five-year-old company that just opened a 10,000-square-foot showroom in Queens, is an example of what happens when fashion meets furniture.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force

item.title: How to Talk About Money in Your Relationship, According to a Personal Finance Coach
item.description: Ramit Sethi, a personal finance author and coach, offers four lessons to help you stop arguing about money in your relationship and start living a “rich life” together.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset: Photo by Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: Street Style Look of the Week: Leopard Pants
item.description: Against an ensemble’s dark shades, a bold animal print jumped out.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha

item.title: Vanity Fair’s New Hollywood Issue, First Under New Editor, Is All About Men
item.description: Mark Guiducci gave his first issue of Vanity Fair over to the guys.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: The Most Impactful Political Handbag Since Mrs. Thatcher’s
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, the new prime minister of Japan, makes a statement about work — with style.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan carrying her trademark Hamano tote, which sold out after her election.

item.title: She Knows What Gen Z Is Thinking
item.description: Callie Holtermann, who covers entertainment, internet culture and trends, combs TikTok — and her own conversations with friends — for story ideas.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Sex Had Become a Chore. Then They Started Reading Romantasy.
item.description: The wildly popular fiction genre allows readers to talk openly about yearning, sex and desire. And it’s spilling over into their bedrooms.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: A Court of Thorns and Roses (Book)

item.title: With New Condé M. Nast Galleries, the Met Museum Gets Fashion Forward
item.description: The Costume Institute is bringing its annual blockbuster show to a permanent home off the Grand Hall, thanks to Anna Wintour’s efforts to get “out of the basement.”
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin and Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Museum will name a new ground-floor gallery for the American publishing entrepreneur Condé Nast and feature its blockbuster Costume Institute show right off the Great Hall.

item.title: Carter Anderson’s Jeans Are Gigantic. His Internet Fame Is Too.
item.description: Carter Anderson purchased an outrageous pair of pants to try to win a contest and became an unlikely social media star along the way.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher and Saeed Rahbaran
item.media:credit: Saeed Rahbaran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carter Anderson’s giant jeans recall the swaying arms of inflatable tube men.

item.title: Epstein Emails Reveal a Lost New York
item.description: The disgraced financier’s recently released documents are steeped in a clubby world that is all but gone.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Rick Friedman/Corbis, via Getty Images

item.title: A Pill for Women’s Libido Meets a Cultural Moment
item.description: A decade ago, Cindy Eckert struggled to convince skeptics about a drug for premenopausal women. Lately, her business is booming.
item.dc:creator: Issie Lapowsky
item.media:credit: Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cindy Eckert, the chief executive of Sprout, the company behind Addyi, a prescription drug that treats hypoactive sexual desire disorder, or H.S.D.D.

item.title: Jordan Firstman of ‘I Love LA’ on Past Lives, Good Fortune and ‘English Teacher’
item.description: “Past-life regression therapy” has taught the 34-year-old actor gratitude. Now a star of HBO’s “I Love LA,” he can see how good he’s got it.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Adam Powell for The New York Times
